POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of North Texas hosted a meeting of linguistic experts working with genetically closely related languages to explore consensus building on shared annotation standards for Interlinear Glossed Texts (IGT).  IGT is a popular output of language documentation projects.  IGT allows linguists to represent language data with granular translations at the clause, word, and affix levels.  This data format is a powerful way to discover and illustrate grammatical description.  However, data formats and annotation standards vary widely for transcribed and translated linguistic data.  This means the data cannot be readily mined for hypothesis testing and typological discovery.  

Three sessions at the 53rd International Conference on Sino-Tibetan Languages featured experts’ conversation on:

  • Session 1: Standards and procedures for the creation of Interlinear Gloss Texts (IGT)
  • Session 2: A generalized ontology for annotating linguistic concepts for related languages
  • Session 3: Metadata for linguistic concepts in digital and legacy archival materials

We documented recommendations from experts in a white paper focusing on lessons learned including:  the power of cross corpora comparison for grammatical analysis, reuse of archived data through improved metadata, and incorporation of information of legacy data into current investigations for improved analysis and results.  Recordings, presentations, and discussion are available through the UNT Digital Library and on YouTube (search 03 NSF Special Session IGT part 1).  

 

Another outcome of this funding was the following publication:

Chelliah, Shobhana, Mary Burke, and Marty Heaton. (2021). Using interlinear gloss texts to facilitate cross-language comparison and improve language description.  Indian Linguistics. Indian Linguistics 82(1-2) 2021: 1-24.

Here we reviewed a study of several IGT examples in published works and based on this discussed how interlinear-glossed text (IGT) represents semantic, morphological and phonological information about lexemes along with phrase and clause level translations of connected text in those published works. While general standards are available to linguists through guidelines such as the Leipzig Glossing Rules (LGR, we argue here that language-family specific guidelines are necessary to facilitate rapid creation of new interpretable IGT that can be used for language description, typological discovery, and cross-language comparison. We look specifically at the representation of reduplication, verb stem alternation, directionals.  We offer some remarks on the purposes of IGT and some principles for new IGT creators.

To test our model of IGT representation, we worked on an IGT collection of the languages of the Barak Valley which can be found here:  Haokip, Pauthang; Chelliah, Shobhana Lakshmi (series editor); Burke, Mary & Heaton, Marty (volume editors). Annotated Texts of the Languages of the Barak Valley: Thadou, Saihriem, Hrangkhol, Ranglong, book, 2021; Denton, Texas. (https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc1808476/: accessed February 11, 2022), University of North Texas Libraries, UNT Digital Library, https://digital.library.unt.edu.

 

Finally, we wrote a manual which is available as an open source text to help others implement IGT decisions:

Chelliah, Shobhana and Samson Lotven.  2021. (release date January 2023) From Source to Analysis:  A fieldworker’s guide to Annotation.  UNT open books.
